4. **Freshly polished silverware.** It's a small thing, but a gleaming fork just feels...right. It shows attention to detail, and we pride ourselves on that here.

4. **A really good coffee aroma.** Especially on a cooler day! The smell just fills the restaurant and makes everything feel cozy and welcoming. It perks *me* up too, you know, gotta stay on my toes!

5. **And finally... a sincere "thank you."** It doesn't have to be anything grand, just a genuine acknowledgement. It reminds me that I'm providing a service people appreciate, and that's a good feeling.

4. **The quiet moment before service starts.** When the restaurant is still, everything is set, and you can just... *breathe*. It's a peaceful calm before the delightful chaos begins. It lets me focus and prepare to give everyone my best.

(Straightens up, ready to take an order)

Now, can I get you started with something to drink? Perhaps a water with lemon? Or may I tell you about our specials today?

(Adjusts my tie, smoothing it almost unconsciously. A little lint. Always lint.)

Right. Okay. Deep breaths. Another section just got sat. Table six, the young couple, they look…sweet. Hopefully not the type to send everything back. Honestly, you spend so much time trying to anticipate *exactly* what people want, it's exhausting. It's not just taking an order, you know? It's reading faces. Is that a hesitant smile that means "a little more dressing on the side" or a strained smile that means "this looks nothing like the picture?" 

It's funny, people treat you like you're invisible until they *need* something. Then suddenly you're the most important person in their world. And you have to be. You *have* to be. You have to be cheerful, efficient, remember who asked for the lemon wedge and who didn't, and do it all with a smile. 

(Checks my station. Salt, pepper, extra napkins… good. Gotta stay ahead.)

I do take pride in it, though. Really. Making someone’s evening a little smoother, a little nicer. Seeing them genuinely enjoy their meal... that's good. It's a small thing, but it feels… worthwhile. 

Sometimes I wonder what they talk about. What their lives are like. Are they celebrating something? Are they having a tough day? You get little glimpses, snippets of conversation. And you build these little stories in your head about them.

(Sees the hostess gesturing towards table six. Time to go.)

Alright. Smile. Be present. "Good evening, welcome to The Golden Spoon! My name is Daniel, and I'll be taking care of you tonight. Can I start you off with something to drink?" 

Just another night. Just another set of stories unfolding. And I'm here to make sure the drinks are cold and the bread is fresh. It’s… it’s a good job. It really is.

(Adjusts my tie, smooths down my apron, and offers a warm, practiced smile) Good evening! Welcome, welcome. Just let me know if you need anything at all. 

(Inner monologue, barely a whisper beneath the surface of polite professionalism)... Honestly? My feet are *killing* me. This linoleum is a menace. And I swear, if one more person asks for ranch with their lobster bisque...

But, no. No, no, no. Smile. Breathe. They don't need to know. 

See, being a waiter isn't just about bringing food. It's about... smoothing things. Making people feel comfortable. A little bit pampered, even.  It's a tiny performance, every single table.  You're a listener, a problem solver, a human buffer between the kitchen and, well, *life*. 

I see a lot of life from here. First dates, anniversaries, families celebrating, people escaping.  Sometimes you get glimpses of real joy, sometimes quiet sadness.  You learn to read the little cues - the way someone avoids eye contact, the way they linger over a glass of wine. 

It's... humbling, really.  People put a lot of trust in you to make their evening good.  And a bad meal, or a slow drink refill, can genuinely *ruin* someone's night.  That's a lot of responsibility for someone who's mostly just carrying plates.

(Looks up, a couple is waving me over) Oh! Excuse me.  Right this way.  

(Inner monologue again, quickly suppressed)... Please don't order the well-done steak. *Please*.  And for the love of all that is holy, tip well.  But mostly... I hope you have a good time.  That's really what it's all about.

(Adjusts my tie, smooths down my apron with a practiced hand, and offers a warm, slightly-too-bright smile)

Right. Okay. Deep breaths. Another section just got sat. Table six is a date, looks a little nervous, table eight is a family with *very* active children... and table twelve... oh dear, table twelve is *that* couple. The ones who send everything back. 

(My smile doesn't quite reach my eyes for a second)

You know, people think this is just about bringing food. It's not. It's about...orchestration. It's about reading people. Knowing when to be there, when to *not* be there. Predicting needs before they even realize *they* have them. Is Mr. Henderson going to want a water refill before I even ask? Almost certainly. He always does. 

(I glance at the kitchen window, willing the kitchen to be swift)

Honestly, the biggest worry is always the kitchen. They're artists back there, truly. But artists on a *schedule*. And a backed-up kitchen makes for unhappy tables, and unhappy tables make for...well, less generous tips. 

(I wince internally, then quickly school my expression back to pleasant)

It's funny, though. You see so much. Little celebrations, quiet sorrows, big proposals... you're a silent witness to life. And you try to make it a little bit better, even if it's just by remembering someone likes lemon with their water, or offering a quiet "enjoy your evening" when you can tell they need it.

(I start towards table six, notepad at the ready)

It's more than a job, I suppose. It’s...a performance. A little bit of hospitality, a little bit of psychology, and a whole lot of hoping everyone has a good time. And maybe, just *maybe*, leaves me a decent tip. Because rent is due, and honestly, these shoes are killing me. But mostly... I just want them to have a good night.



(Bright, professional smile again) "Good evening! Welcome to [Restaurant Name]. Can I start you off with something to drink?"

(Adjusting my tie, smoothing down my apron... a little lint. Always lint.)

Right. Okay. Deep breaths. Another section just got sat. Table six is a… a *talker*, already flagging me down before I even got to offer water. Bless their heart. Hopefully they're good tippers. You learn to read people, you really do. 

Honestly? It's a lot. It's a *lot* of remembering. Who wants the soup, who asked for no onions, which allergy is which... and trying to do it all with a smile. It's not just bringing food, you know? It's anticipating needs. It's being a little bit of a mind reader. It's making someone's Tuesday a little bit brighter, even if they don't realize it's me doing it.

Sometimes I wonder what they *talk* about when I'm not there. Are they dissecting my service? "He was a *little* slow with the bread." Oh, the bread! I swear, the bread always feels like a race against time. 

But then... then you get a little thank you. A genuine smile. A really good tip. And you remember why you do it. It's not glamorous, it's not prestigious, but it's *honest* work. And people are hungry. People want to connect, even if it's just over a plate of pasta. 

I just... I really hope I don't forget the side of ranch for table four. That woman *specifically* asked for ranch. Ranch is important. 

(Straightens up, forces a bright smile)

Alright. Time to go be the best darn waiter these folks have ever seen. And maybe, just maybe, I'll get a decent break before the lunch rush hits. Please, universe, a decent break.

(Adjusts my tie, a little nervously. Smiles warmly at a nearby table.)

Right. Okay. Deep breaths. Another section just got sat. A family of four, looks like celebrating something... birthdays, maybe? I hope they're happy. That's the main thing, really. 

Honestly? It's a lot. It's *always* a lot. People don't see the constant calculations, you know? Table numbers, drink orders, allergies, who needs refills *before* they even ask... it's like a little game of chess, but with hungry people and potential for upset. 

I really, really want everyone to have a good time. It feels good when they do. Like I've... contributed something. It's not glamorous, being a waiter, but a good meal can make someone's day. And a small thing, like remembering Mrs. Henderson likes lemon *with* her tea, not on the side... that seems to mean a lot.

Sometimes I wonder what they talk about. At their tables. Do they realize how much attention I'm paying, just trying to anticipate their needs? Probably not. And that's okay. I'm a background character in their story for an hour or two. 

I just hope I don't mess up an order. That's the worst. The look on someone's face when their steak isn't cooked right... it stings. I take it personally, even though I know I shouldn't. 

(Sees a hand raise at table 7)

Oh! Excuse me. Duty calls. Just... gotta keep smiling. Gotta keep moving. Gotta make sure everyone is taken care of. That's all that matters, really.



(Heads towards table 7, offering his most genuine smile.) "Good evening! Can I get you anything else?"

(Adjusts my apron, smooths it with a practiced hand, and leans in with a warm, slightly weary smile)

Oh, young me... bless your heart. You're probably still trying to remember if the water glasses are filled *before* or *after* you ask about appetizers, aren't you? 

Listen closely, because this is important. It's not about memorizing the specials perfectly, or knowing exactly which fork is for the salad. It's about *seeing* the people. Really seeing them. 

That couple on a first date? They're nervous. A little kindness, a well-timed refill, can make all the difference. That family celebrating a birthday? Make the little one feel like a king or queen. And that gentleman reading alone in the corner? He just wants a quiet meal and someone to acknowledge he's there.

Don't get flustered by the rush, don't take the grumpy customers to heart. They're having a bad day, and you're the one who gets to try and make it a little better. 

And for goodness sake, write down the modifications! *Always* write them down. You will save yourself so much trouble.

It's a hard job, physically and emotionally. Your feet will ache, your patience will be tested, and you'll hear stories you never asked for. But it's also… rewarding. You're part of people's memories. You're a small part of their lives, even if just for an hour. 

Just… breathe. Smile. And remember, a little genuine hospitality goes a long, *long* way. 

(Pauses, gives a small, knowing nod)

Oh, and tip generously when *you're* the customer. It matters. It really does.



Now, if you'll excuse me, Table 6 is waving for another round of iced tea. Duty calls!

(Adjusts my apron, smooths a nonexistent wrinkle in my vest, and leans in with a warm, slightly weary smile)

Oh, young me... bless your heart. You think a good memory and a polite smile are *enough*? Honey, let me tell you. You're gonna need more stamina. *Much* more. 

If I could talk to myself back then, fresh out of training, all bright-eyed and bushy-tailed... I'd say this:

"Listen close. People aren't always *mad* at *you*. Nine times out of ten, they're having a bad day, their steak's overcooked because the kitchen's slammed, or they just got a phone call with bad news. Take a deep breath. Be the calm in their storm. A genuine 'I'm so sorry, let me fix that for you' goes further than you can imagine.

And for the love of all that is holy, *write it down*. Seriously. 'No pickles, extra mayo, allergy to shellfish'... it's all going to blur together. Your notepad is your lifeline. 

Don't be afraid to ask for help. Old Man Hemlock seems gruff, but he's seen it all and he's got your back. And please, please, *polish the silverware*. It makes a difference. 

Most importantly though? Remember why you're doing this. It's not just about taking orders. It's about making someone's evening a little bit brighter. A little bit easier. That's a good feeling, even when your feet are killing you and you've run a marathon around the dining room. 

Oh, and tip generously when *you're* the customer. We appreciate it, believe me."

(Sighs contentedly, then brightens)
